+Sahil Zubair If you believe there's a problem.  I don't.

I realize it's semantics, but in the VAST majority of cases, drilling and 
recovering oil and gas does not really pollute the environment.  The manner 
in which we consume them does...however not having that energy is far more 
dangerous to far more people.

If you give a shit about third world people, we should continue to consume 
their oil.  Basic economics...and unless they live in a dictatorship 
there's no way they don't all benefit from having someone to sell it to. 
 Certainly there are places where that's been the case, but that isn't 
really an argument against oil is it?

Presumably unlike most people commenting, I've worked in oil fields in 
South America, North America, and Western Africa.  I don't take the poverty 
in those countries lightly, and in many of the countries I've worked in I'd 
like to see tremendous changes.  Simply not consuming one of the few 
products they have to offer is not remotely beneficial to anyone in those 
countries.

I'm also not opposed to drilling in America...done properly it is safe and 
undeniably a positive thing.  Have some companies done dangerous things 
like fracture wells in the fresh water zone?  Yes, that's happened both out 
of ignorance and incompetence.  Feel free to sue the shit out of them, 
that's how you stop that behavior.

This guy is a driller, not a Fracker. I Fracked Gas wells for Dowell 
Schlumberger  in Alberta & Saskatchewan in 1975. It was filthy work. We 
pumped Sand, Water, HCl, HFl, Liquid CO2, KCl, NaCl down the well under up 
to 10,000 psi. After the well fractured, we'd strip out all the Pump Gear 
and then open up the well and let it blow all over the prairie. Made a hell 
of a mess, but the chemicals kept the weeds down. All that effluent is 
captured today. I didn't like the work and it was very poorly paid in the 
1970's. I gave that up and went into Gas Distribution as a Engineering 
Designer. Much cleaner Office work, well paid, but not near as exciting!﻿

+cdnski12 I worked 7 months for Nabors in Williston, ND right after 
graduating high school and was laid off in January 2015. We didn't blow out 
the chemicals after fracking but dragging the piping out of the ground in 
subzero temps sucked and plenty was spilled during pumping. I miss it, I 
worked 14 on and 7 off (80-120 hours a week) $18 an hour. Now I work 40 
hours a week and only make $12 an hour. I'm looking into applying for a 
security job at a mine but I'm weary of being laid off because their stocks 
dropped from $27 dollars a share to $3.

+Ducky1521 
That was an entry job. At that time, all my fellow workers probably had 
Grade 10-12 High School. I have a 2 year  Diploma from the BC Institute of 
Technology in Natural Gas & Oil Technology. I had 4 years of Pipeline 
Construction Design Work. So I was the highest educated person on the job, 
other than the Site Engineer. I quit after 6 months, because the pay was so 
poor in the late 1970's. I went back to my previous job, designing Gas 
Pipelines. Much cleaner and better paid.

Destroying the environment how!? The water injected into the soil is 99.5% 
water, the remaining stuff is HCl, guar gum, ascorbic acid, Nitrogen, KCl 
and other stuff...The rock that is being fractured is well below the water 
table and soil layer. The well is also solidly cased with three layers of 
steel and cement (nothing but water and hydrocarbons are getting in or out 
of the well). So, because of how pressure works, well, the water would only 
go out of the well instead of seeping above into the water table that's far 
above with many layers of impermeable rock in between. Earthquakes? Yeah, 
maybe on a scale of 1.5 or 2 on the Richter scale which is unnoticeable and 
on a lower magnitude than a subway train (3). Earthquakes on that scale 
happen everyday, unnoticed. The scary stuff is actually the used water 
coming out of the well. As it fractures the rock, it dissolves it too and 
becomes richer in salts and radioactive elements (mud-rock or shale is 
radioactive). So that water needs to be treated (and companies do that) and 
not dumped into the earth, because it will cause huge problems.  I am a 
Geology undergrad, these are my 2 cents. ﻿

+offisk dahl Couple things to add: Fracking a well in ND uses on average 
about 2 million gallons of water which comes from nearby oil wells (which 
produce water along with oil) - this water is not coming out of our water 
tables. The toxic water is pumped to the bottom of the well during fracking 
and is kept away from the water table for the same reasons that the oil 
that has been down there for millions of years hasn't seeped into the water 
table - geological traps. There are isolated cases of fracking fluids found 
in water tables but according to the EPA it is not a systemic problem 
inherent to the process. It is expected to have a certain % of incidents 
given how large the industry is. Every industry has accidents and this one 
is within normal incident rates. Most accidents are surface spills when 
semi-trucks hired to transport it leak or crash and the water leaks out and 
can flow into the water table.

+Goddard Entertainment  I think you might be confusing net worth v.s. 
annual income. Though a net worth of $250K would not be anywhere close to 
being considered wealthy, a  income of $250K a year would put the subject 
of this video in the top 2% of income earners nationally. That means his 
income bracket/class (the 2%), earns 24% of ALL INCOME annually among 
Americans and pays 44% of all federal income taxes.

 In this country we are so use to hearing of athletes, musicians, media 
stars, etc. making 10's of millions, or CEO making hundreds of millions to 
billions in a single year as their income, our perspective becomes 
distorted and we start to think that a figure like $250K in salary must be 
middle class, and chump change, when the OPPOSITE is true.

Those making even a $1M to several million in yearly income is 
extremely...extremely rare statistically and as a ratio of the population 
 in a country of 300  + million people (let alone on a planet of 7 billion) 
are to be considered outliers (billions a year is even rarer), so someone 
who makes $250K a year, is from an income perspective able to generate and 
accumulate wealth at a rapid rate v.s. the average person (per capita 
income)  whose is likely to be taking in $28K annually and $52k for a 
family of four (median household income).

 The point is that not as many people as you think make a yearly income of 
$250K - not even the average small business owner does, most are lucky if 
their business is able after operating expenses, taxes,etc. to generate 
$100K for themselves personally - so some perspective is in order, even 
though that's hard to do in our materialistic culture where money in the 
ultimate god of our nation.
